intro: Acalypha purpurascens var. genuina, commonly known as the red-leaf kochia, is a shrub native to tropical and subtropical regions. It features striking, velvety red or purple leaves that are often variegated with green, making it a popular ornamental plant. The plant produces small, inconspicuous greenish flowers that are clustered in cylindrical spikes. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, exhibiting drought tolerance once established. Its foliage is known for its vibrant coloration, which intensifies in cooler temperatures.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha purpurascens var. genuina is primarily native to the southern United States, specifically Texas and northern Mexico. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and along riverbanks. This variety is adapted to hot, dry climates and is commonly seen in desert regions. It is also known for its striking red and purple foliage, which makes it a popular ornamental plant. Its native range includes parts of the Chihuahuan Desert and the Edwards Plateau.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha purpurascens var. genuina was mainly introduced to Hawaii. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and unique appearance. The plant has since spread beyond cultivated areas and is now found in various habitats across the islands. It is considered invasive in some regions because of its rapid growth and ability to outcompete native species. Its distribution is now widespread throughout the Hawaiian archipelago.
